section.title: Introduction
section.para: Many pages generated in your "onCourse" website will be content automatically generated from your Course, Classes, and Tutor descriptions. Some of the pages in your site have URLs like this: /courses /courses/arts/photography /course/ABC /sites /tutor/123 /site/234 /enrol

These are pages which are automatically handled and generated by onCourse Web. You will want to create a whole set of pages for your site to suit your own needs. The content management system (CMS) allows you to add additional content to add breadth and cohesion to your website. For example, you may like to add an "about us" or "contact" page; these additions are handled by the CMS.

section.title: Setting Up Log In Access to the CMS
section.para: Before you start editing content within the CMS you need to set up a user name and password to log in.

onCourse enables any user to also have the ability to log into and edit content within the CMS using the same log in credentials for the CMS that you use to access the onCourse Client . To do this go to File > Preferences > Users and open the relevant record, then tick the box to allow the user to edit the CMS.

caption.para: Enabling CMS Access within onCourse User Profile

section.title: Logging in
section.para: Log into the CMS by visiting your normal live site and adding /cms/login to the end. For example, if your site is http://www.acme.com.au, your CMS will be accessed at http://www.acme.com.au/cms/login

section.title: Finding your way around
section.para:
Finding your way around the CMS
Once logged in, a new toolbar will be visible on the bottom of the browser window. You can continue to browse through your site as normal, and when you reach a page you'd like to edit, the toolbar gives you the options to do so.
Across the bottom of your screen you will find two grey bars. The bottom bar allows you to quickly access the primary areas of the CMS (each of which are explained in detail below).
The upper bar concerns itself with specific information about the page you are currently browsing - for example, its published state and when it was last edited.

Running your mouse over the page content will highlight any text panels that are available to edit. An "Edit Content" button will appear in the top, right hand corner of any editable panel... clicking this, you gain access to the text editor.

listitem.para: Page Options This panel allows you to set options for control and display of the current page. This includes the URL, page name and theme.
Current Page the "Current Page" item will allow you to quickly jump between documents at the top level of the navigation hierarchy of your site.
Publication status and Last Edit Once your page is published the 'publication status' will change to a red "published"; also displayed to the right is the last edit date.
Show Editable Areas at the extreme right is a slide that highlights all the editable areas on the page.

section.title: Creating a new Web page
section.para: Press the Add new page button in the toolbar at the bottom. A page options panel slides up ready for you to enter details.

Give your new page a name and click the Save button. We now have a new page with a headline and a small introductory sentence already in place. Congratulations... you're on your way with onCourse CMS webpage creation.

section.title: Content Editing
section.para: Say you have a news page on your site and you'd like to update it. Log into the CMS and navigate to the page you want to edit. When you roll your mouse over the text area on the page you'll see an edit content link which you can click on. Make sure you ensure that the Show editable area button is switched on. Once you have clicked, a dialog will appear which allows you to edit the content of that area directly.

caption.para: Edit window to access and update page content

tip.para: When navigating to a page to edit the content, it is best to search for the page via the search filter on the page menu or alternatively update the URL to the page you wish to edit. If you attempt to navigate to the page by clicking on the web pages itself, you may inadvertently edit the wrong page.

section.title: Page options
section.para: Every CMS page on your site has a number of page options which you can edit. You are not able to modify page options for core system pages generated automatically by the system (such as /courses).

caption.para: Page options that are available for each page within the Content Management System

listitem.para: If the page is not visible it will not appear in navigation, search results or in menus. However if you are logged into the CMS you will be able to see and edit these unpublished pages.

caption.para: To publish or remove a given page from your website, simply set the page visibility accordingly

listitem.para: All pages will always be accessible by their internal reference. That link (URL) will look like http://www.acme.com.au/page/123. However you will probably want to define more accessible URLs like /contact or /about/jobs or whatever suits your sitemap and your overall goals.
You can add as many links as you like to each page, but you cannot remove the initial /page/123 style link which is used to identify the page.

caption.para: You can easily set up more than 1 Page Link (URL) as well as defining the default link

listitem.para: Each page has a theme which defines the look of the page and which blocks are visible on that page. You can drag and drop your CMS blocks into position for each theme that you create for your website. If you don't assign a page theme when you first create a new page, the default page theme will be applied.

caption.para: Editing Themes - applying CMS blocks to a given theme

tip.para: The pagetheme is a default theme that is applied to all special pages within the CMS such as /courses or /sites. It therefore cannot be deleted within the CMS
